text:
Dani, you should first look into the goal for SEO. Is it just bringing in random traffic / grow organically and start getting leads / improve DA / or some other goal.

I have been in the SEO space for more than 7 years now and have worked across websites from different niches and have seen how SEO has evolved over the years.

There was a time SEOs would just look at the referring domain DA for building links. Things like bookmarking, infographic submission, etc. were working those days.

Things have changed. Google as a search engine has evolved. It is smart & it's AI thinks more more like a human I'd say.

For your question, building links from your niche or your shoulder niche (which is relevant) is the way to go.

Instead of just looking at the DA, You should look more into the kind of keywords that is getting to the referring domain traffic.

This way you get quality links & referral traffic/leads.

The simple thing to think here is,

What's point of placing a link in a content which nobody is going to click?

My mantra has always been to stick to quality instead of quantity :slightly_smiling_face:


And Yes, producing quality content on your website can get you a lot of organic links.

text:
Hello all! I was wondering how (or if?) your teams guard against *plagiarism when outsourcing content*? 

We recently tried using some content agencies for a bulk of our articles, and have been hearing about cases of plagiarism. (Agency says the articles are checked, but these are understandably tricky to catch.) 

Do you have any recommended tools, guidelines, or general thoughts on the matter?

elements.text: Hello all! I was wondering how (or if?) your teams guard against
plagiarism when outsourcing content

? 

We recently tried using some content agencies for a bulk of our articles, and have been hearing about cases of plagiarism. (Agency says the articles are checked, but these are understandably tricky to catch.) 

Do you have any recommended tools, guidelines, or general thoughts on the matter?

text: I also had to start running plagiarism checks after an issue with an agency. I currently just use free results in Google and really don't have a great grasp on which work best.

elements.text: I also had to start running plagiarism checks after an issue with an agency. I currently just use free results in Google and really don't have a great grasp on which work best.

text: I'm considering ProWritingAid premium, which includes 50 plagiarism checks a year (I'd need more, so I have to see if it's possible). But I'm going to be using the full features of the tool, which includes corrections based on style guide, grammar edits, etc. If you wouldn't, I'm sure there's better options if you just need a plagiarism check.

It’s a good start, but thinking a manual check is still needed.

text:
Yes a million times — we build this into our content editing at our agency because we've had so many freelancers plagiarize content. I tried using Grammarly's plagiarism detector, but honestly it wasn't picking up a lot that I was finding manually searching on Google.

I found <https://www.quetext.com/> is the resource that has identified plagiarized writing the best of any that we've used. (To Ryan's comment, PWA is also a great tool but I don't know if their plagiarism detector is stellar or not.)

The best way I've found to catch it up front is to note when a writer's level or tone changes quite a bit randomly throughout the piece. If I see that happening, I might start Googling sentences to see if my hunch is correct... but Quetext has revealed far more matched or near-matched sentences than any of the other tools I tried, so we just use them now. (Plus, it's like $10/month for a paid plan, which is pretty hard to beat.)

I dealt with this _very_ recently and have started working on some plagiarism standards/training that I'm going to disseminate to all new writers moving forward. If you want me to send along what I come up with, I'd be happy to do it when I'm done!

attachments.text: Plagiarism Checker by Quetext. Our proprietary DeepSearch™ plagiarism checker searches for similarities across billions of documents
attachments.title: Original Writing, Made Easy | Quetext

text: Hello! Not all of our members are guys. In an effort to be more conscious of the language we use to address each other, why not try “Hey, folks,” or “Hey everyone” instead?

I do own a b2b content strategy agency and we do a extensive check on every new writer we bring on-board for our clients. This means not only the writing style but also ability to research, drive conclusions and write content based on objective facts.
Once the vetting is done, we really on trust and we haven’t had issues with anyone so far.

elements.text:
I do own a b2b content strategy agency and we do a extensive check on every new writer we bring on-board for our clients. This means not only the writing style but also ability to research, drive conclusions and write content based on objective facts.
Once the vetting is done, we really on trust and we haven’t had issues with anyone so far.

text: We run our writers’ copy through Copyscape, that’s about it. In 3 years, and dealing with hundreds of blogs, never had an issue (or at least blatant / intentional, sometimes there’s only so many ways to define a term, or some concepts in industries like compliance or finance have to be worded the same per official guidance). Never anyone lifting work from another writer or source.

elements.text: We run our writers’ copy through Copyscape, that’s about it. In 3 years, and dealing with hundreds of blogs, never had an issue (or at least blatant / intentional, sometimes there’s only so many ways to define a term, or some concepts in industries like compliance or finance have to be worded the same per official guidance). Never anyone lifting work from another writer or source.

text:
Yeah, slowly coming to the conclusion that similar wording can’t be avoided (there are only so many ways you can define a term). :woman-shrugging::skin-tone-2:

But to keep an eye out for citing quotes and sources, or claiming ownership of another person’s ideas.

elements.text: Yeah, slowly coming to the conclusion that similar wording can’t be avoided (there are only so many ways you can define a term).
But to keep an eye out for citing quotes and sources, or claiming ownership of another person’s ideas.

text: we use grammarly's plagiarism checker and it's caught a few instances of plagiarism whenever we try out new writers. i've noticed that people who plagiarize will often copy from the top-ranking content, so it's done a great job of helping us weed out writers and ensure the copy we're writing is unique

text: Howdy, content marketers! We're taking over an email list for a pretty well-known author which is great, but we have minimal historical data and a whole lotta dormant contacts in the database. One of the ways we're getting to understand the audience is by segmenting the list and sending some surveys. I'm aware just about everyone is sending surveys these days so we're going to be careful with the approach and be sure they get something out of it. My Q for y'all: Does anyone have angles/concepts that worked for surveys re: getting people to actually fill it out? Thanks for any insights

text:
Content calendar question for the Asana folks out there (after a round of googling and desperation :slightly_smiling_face:)

I want one project to be the content calendar in kanban view so that everyone has visibilty on my pipeline, and that parts easy. Seems like that's how most orgs do it. But I keep getting stuck on subtasks... they don't show up in any of my overall views and I need to know where everything is at a glance, when my blog posts are all necessarily single tasks in this view. According to their blog, it seems like that's by design?

I'm used to Todoist (which I much prefer) and that app treated subtasks as real tasks in the main views. So maybe I'm missing something really obvious, but would love to hear from you all on how you handle this! I'd love to implement an airtable/asana automated setup but I think I'm going to lose that battle until our publishing cadence goes up.

Really appreciate any help y'all can provide!
